ygData.subject: Re: Does NEAT Facilitate Link Values of 0, max and min?
ygData.msgSnippet: There s nothing in NEAT that drives outputs to 0, however the CPPN throws out any output that is within [-0.2,0.2].  If it didn t do this, all substrates

There's nothing in NEAT that drives outputs to 0, however the CPPN throws o=
ut any output that is within [-0.2,0.2].  If it didn't do this, all substra=
tes created by CPPNs would be fully connected.  If you look at NEAT_Layered=
Substrate.h, you will see convertOutputToWeight(...), which converts the ou=
tput form the CPPN into a substrate weight magnitude.

I believe part of th=
e reason why values are set to -3 or 3 is more complex:  Because there isn'=
t normalization in the basic HyperNEAT algorithm, there is competition betw=
een the link weights to have influence, so there's an arms race towards ver=
y high (or low) link weights.

Also note that if you do not have a bias cod=
e in your CPPN, the connection going from (0,0) to (0,0) will be 0 every ti=
me because the network has no inputs of value.

Jason G.

groups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello all-
> 
> I was just l=
ooking at some NEAT genomes and noticed that they have many link
> values o=
f exactly -3 (min), 3 (max), and 0.
> 
> Does NEAT have something that faci=
litates the production of max, min and 0?
> I know HyperNEAT facilitates th=
e production of zeros...does NEAT?
> 
> PS. I am using Jason's HyperNEAT C+=
+ package, in case that is different in
> this respect. 
>

 any thoughts, I would appreciate it. It is affecting an
